Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial of Perioperative Normoxia vs. Hyperoxia in Cyanotic Neonates Undergoing Cardiopulmonary Bypass

Participants.evidence: neonates with cyanotic congenital heart disease at a single tertiary care center. Eligibility criteria included neonates requiring cardiopulmonary bypass.

Intervention.evidence: Participants were randomised to normoxia (PaO2 60–100 mmHg) or hyperoxia (PaO2 200–300 mmHg) during bypass.

Objective.evidence: This study assesses the feasibility, safety, and oxidative stress response of perioperative normoxia versus hyperoxia in cyanotic neonates undergoing cardiopulmonary bypass.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was serum thiobarbituric acid reactive substances (TBARS) measured at baseline, 2, 6, and 24 hours postoperatively.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was computer-generated, and allocation was concealed.

Number_Randomised.evidence: Twenty-nine neonates (median age 5 days) were randomised: 15 to normoxia and 14 to hyperoxia.

Result_Outcome.evidence: TBARS levels were significantly lower in the normoxia group at 2 hours (1.21±0.26 vs 1.93±0.63), 6 hours (1.09±0.25 vs 1.77±0.7), and 24 hours (0.96±0.16 vs 1.41±0.29); all p<0.01.

Harms.evidence: No severe adverse events were reported.
